textBibliography.frontMatter: THE ARRAIGNMENT, TRYAL, AND CONDEMNATION OF THOMAS HARRISON LATE MAJOR GENERAL, AND ONE OF THE PRETENDED JUDGES THAT SIGN'D THE WARRANT FOR THE MURDER OF KING CHARLES THE FIRST, OF EVER BLESSED MEMORY, AND APPOINTED THE PLACE FOR THAT FATAL EXECUTION TO BE AT WHITE-HALL GATE. (...) (LONDON) PRINTED FOR T. VERE, AND W. GILBERTSON. 1660. PP. 4.1 - 7.29

dialogueText.dialogue: Hardresse Waller Knight, hold up thy hand, what sayest thou, art thou guilty of this horrid Act of Treason whereof thou standest indicted, or not guilty .
My Lord, I cannot say, I am not guilty.

dialogue.font: Then you plead, you are guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: Yes my Lord, I am guilty.
Set him aside. Thomas Harison, Hold up thy hand, art thou guilty or not guilty .
If I should say I am not guilty, I should wrong my own conscience, yet in matter and form as it is laid down in this Indictment, I am not guilty.
Then you plead not guilty.

My Lord, I desire I may have counsell afforded me, and time to make my defence, for I have been kept close prisoner in a dark Chamber, and had no notice of my Tryal till five of the clock in the morning, that I am altogether unprepared.

dialogue.font: You are to plead guilty or not guilty, for in cases of Treason Counsel is not to be assigned, for that would make it justifiable, and that it were not Treason, and you would be quit, but if it be treason, then it is not justifiable.

dialogueText.dialogue: I am not guilty.

dialogue.font: How wilt thou be tryed.

dialogueText.dialogue: By the Lords Lawes, and by the good and wholesome Laws of the Land.

dialogue.font: Wilt thou be tryed by God and the Countrey.

dialogueText.nonSpeech: Har. He answered that was a profane word.

dialogue.font: he shall be turned over to God and the Countrey.
No Sir, I will be tryed by God and the Country.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance,
Henry Heveningham, hold up thy hand, guilty or not guilty .
Not guilty.

dialogue.font: How wilt thou be tryed.

dialogueText.dialogue: I will present an humble Petition to His Majesty and the Parliament, and desire your Lordships to let me return to my lodgings in the Tower, for I have some infirmities upon me.

dialogue.font: We can give you no answer to that,

dialogueText.dialogue: How wilt thou be tryed?

dialogue.font: By God and the Countrey.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance. Set them by, Bring Isaac Pennington, Henry Martin, Gilbert Millington, Robert Tichborn, and Robert Lilborn to the Bar .
Henry Martin, Hold up thy hand to the Bar, what sayest thou, art guilty of this horrid act of Treason whereof thou standest indicted or not guilty .
My Lord, I desire the benefit of the Act of Indempnity.

dialogue.font: First you are to plead before you can have the benefit of any thing, and for your pleading the Act of Indemnity that makes you guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: My Lord, If I plead, I loose the benefit of that Act.

dialogue.font: Your name is in that Act.

dialogueText.dialogue: My name is not there my Lord, my name is Henry Marten , not Martin ,
there is no difference between Martin and Marten in Law, the difference is very little in the sound,
art thou guilty or not guilty.

be advised, for it makes no difference if there were two names of the like form, the difference is betwixt the six Names, and 'twill but make you a Mute in Law, and a Mute in Treason, Sir, you must have Judgement passed on you .
Are you guilty or not guilty.

dialogue.font: I desire Counsel my Lord in that which is matter of Law.

dialogueText.dialogue: What do you desire counsel for? you are indicted for matter of Treason, for Contriving and Composing the Kings death: you have justification to plead if it be Treason, it is not justifiable; or if it be justifiable, it is not Treason.

dialogue.font: Then my Lord I plead not guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: How will you be tryed?

dialogue.font: By God and the Countrey.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance.

dialogue.font: You may give any Evidence, but in a case of this nature you can give no Evidence.

dialogueText.dialogue:
Gilbert Millingtoun , Hold up thy hand, what sayst thou
art guilty of this horrid Act of Treason or not guilty.

dialogue.font: I humbly crave your Lordships pardon in some few words.

dialogueText.dialogue: Sir we must do in this case as in all other cases, either you must plead guilty or not, if you plead not guilty, you shall be heard hereafter: but you must plead guilty or not guilty.

dialogue.font: There is something in that Indictment which I am not guilty of.

dialogueText.dialogue: Then plead not guilty.

dialogue.font: I am not guilty my Lord.

dialogueText.dialogue: How wilt thou be tryed?

dialogue.font: By God and my Countrey.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance.
Robert Tichborn, hold up thy hand, art thou guilty of this horrid Act of Treason, or not guilty .
My Lord, I have for some space been kept close prisoner, and I am altogether unable in the Law to speak for my self.

dialogue.font: You must plead guilty, or not guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: Spare me one word, if the Tryal be matter of Law, give leave for Counsel to plead for me: if I should plead my own case in Law, I might be overpowred, since there are many persons of great eminency and honour will plead against me, but I will not trouble you long if this be the case in matter and form as I am here Indicted, I am not guilty.

dialogue.font: How wilt thou be tryed?

dialogueText.dialogue: NO SPEAKER NAME GIVEN IN SOURCE TEXT. By God and the Country.

dialogue.font: God send you a good deliverance.

dialogueText.dialogue: Owen Roe, Hold up your hand, art thou guilty of this horrid act of Treason or not guilty.

dialogue.font: My Lord, I will rest upon the Judgement of the Court, in matter and form as I stand indicted, I am not guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: How wilt thou be try'd?

dialogue.font: By God and the Country.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance.
Robert Lilburn, Hold up thy hand, art thou guilty or not guilty ?
I have been close Prisoner my Lord these twenty dayes, and none suffered to come to me, and I am told that I ought to have counsel before I plead.

dialogue.font: You are misinformed, you cannot have it, you must plead guilty or not guilty, for if this be your argument, and this answer return of Iudgement will be given against you, for the rule is set before us.

dialogueText.dialogue: My Lord, if you over rule me, I cannot help it.

dialogue.font: Sir, Pray let no such words fall from your mouth.

dialogueText.dialogue: My Lord, I must say in matter and form as I stand indicted, I am not guilty.

dialogue.font: How wilt thou be try'd?

dialogueText.dialogue: By God and the Country.

dialogue.font: God send thee a good deliverance.

dialogueText.dialogue: Call Adrian Scroop, Augustine Garland, Gregory Clement, Peter Temple, John Jones, Iames Temple, Iohn Cook, Iohn Carew ,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: all which held up their hands as others before by degrees, pleading not guilty?
Afterwards was called Tho. Scot, Henry Smith, Gregory Clement, Vincent Potter, Edmund Harvy, Tho. Wait, Hugh Peters , to hold up their hands and read the Charge,
dialogueText.dialogue: are ye guilty or not guilty?

dialogue.font: I cannot say I am guilty my Lord, for I would not be guilty of the murder for ten thousand Worlds.

dialogueText.dialogue: How wilt thou be tryed.
By the word of God ;
Art thou guilty or not guilty.

dialogue.font: Not guilty.

dialogueText.dialogue: How wilt thou be tryed.

dialogue.font: By God and the Countrey.

dialogueText.dialogue: God send thee a good deliverance.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: George Fleetwood being call'd to the Bar, held up his hand as before, and confest himself guilty: But the others pleaded not guilty .
